conversation.content: She came in with this shoebox full of papers, just completely lost. [empathetically] Her hands were shaking as she set everything on my desk. Twenty-three years of marriage and suddenly she's dealing with survivor benefits, death certificates, forms she'd never seen before. [pause] I remember thinking, this is why I do this job. Not for the paperwork or the bureaucracy, but for moments like this. [warm] We spent three hours going through everything together. Every form, every option, what she was entitled to. She kept apologizing for taking up my time, and I kept telling her this is literally what I'm here for. [chuckle] The relief on her face when I explained she wouldn't lose the pension, that there were survivor benefits specifically designed for her situation... [very sincerely] She actually started crying. Right there in my office. And then she grabbed my hand and said I was the first person who'd made any of this make sense since her husband died. [sigh] You know, people think benefits administration is just pushing papers around. But it's, um... it's really about being there when someone's world has fallen apart. [quietly] Making sure they don't fall through the cracks too. [relieved] She sends me a Christmas card every year now. Says I saved her life that day. [trailing off] Maybe I did...

subject: Your benefits administrator expertise helped a confused widow navigate her husband's pension
